title: Call Option Payoff at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a European call option at expiration. Payoff_C represents the call option payoff
column6: S_T is the underlying asset price at expiration
column7: K is the strike price
column8: and max is the maximum function. The call option gives the right to buy the asset at K
column9: so it's exercised only when S_T > K

title: Put Option Payoff at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a European put option at expiration. Payoff_P represents the put option payoff
column6: S_T is the underlying asset price at expiration
column7: and K is the strike price. The put option gives the right to sell the asset at K
column8: so it's exercised only when S_T < K

title: Call Option Profit at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation calculates the profit from a call option at expiration. Profit_C represents the profit
column6: S_T is the underlying price at expiration
column7: K is the strike price
column8: and C_0 is the initial call option premium paid. Profit accounts for both the payoff and the cost of purchasing the option.

title: Put Option Profit at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation calculates the profit from a put option at expiration. Profit_P represents the profit
column6: S_T is the underlying price at expiration
column7: K is the strike price
column8: and P_0 is the initial put option premium paid. Profit accounts for both the payoff and the cost of purchasing the option.

title: Intrinsic Value (Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation calculates the intrinsic value of a call option. IV_C represents the intrinsic value
column6: S_0 is the current underlying price
column7: and K is the strike price. Intrinsic value represents the immediate exercise value if the option were in the money. For out-of-the-money options

title: Intrinsic Value (Put)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation calculates the intrinsic value of a put option. IV_P represents the intrinsic value
column6: S_0 is the current underlying price
column7: and K is the strike price. Intrinsic value represents the immediate exercise value if the option were in the money.

title: Time Value
notes: This equation calculates the time value of an option. TV represents the time value
column5: Option Price is the current market price
column6: and Intrinsic Value is the immediate exercise value. Time value reflects the probability that the option will move into the money before expiration and decays as expiration approaches.

title: Put-Call Parity
notes: This is the fundamental put-call parity relationship for European options on non-dividend paying stocks. C represents the call price
column5: P is the put price
column6: S_0 is the current stock price
column7: K is the strike price
column10: and e^{-rT} is the discount factor. This no-arbitrage condition links call and put prices.

title: Put-Call Parity with Dividends
equation_latex: C + K * e^{-rT} = P + S_0 * e^{-qT}
notes: This is the put-call parity for European options on dividend-paying stocks. The terms are the same as basic put-call parity
column5: except S_0 is multiplied by e^{-qT} to account for the continuous dividend yield q. Dividends reduce the stock price growth
column6: affecting the parity relationship.

title: Lower Bound for European Call
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation gives the lower bound for a European call option price. C represents the call price
column6: S_0 is the current stock price
column7: K is the strike price
column9: and T is time to expiration. The call price must be at least the intrinsic value of a forward contract

title: Lower Bound for European Put
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column5: This equation gives the lower bound for a European put option price. P represents the put price
column6: S_0 is the current stock price
column7: K is the strike price
column9: and T is time to expiration. The put price must be at least the intrinsic value of a forward contract

title: Upper Bound for European Call
notes: This equation gives the upper bound for a European call option price. C represents the call price
column5: and S_0 is the current stock price. A call option cannot be worth more than the underlying asset itself
column6: as the option gives only the right to buy the asset.

title: Upper Bound for European Put
notes: This equation gives the upper bound for a European put option price. P represents the put price
column5: K is the strike price
column6: r is the risk-free rate
column7: and T is time to expiration. A put option cannot be worth more than the present value of the strike price
column8: as the option gives only the right to receive K at expiration.

title: American Call on Non-Dividend Stock
notes: This equation states that for American calls on non-dividend paying stocks
column5: early exercise is never optimal. C_American represents the American call price
column6: which equals the European call price. The time value is always positive
column7: so it's better to sell the option than exercise it early.

title: American Put on Non-Dividend Stock
notes: This equation states that American puts can be worth more than European puts. P_American represents the American put price
column5: and P_European is the European put price. Early exercise may be optimal for deep in-the-money puts
column6: making the American option more valuable.

title: Black-Scholes Call Formula
notes: This is the famous Black-Scholes formula for pricing a European call option. C represents the call price
column5: S_0 is the current stock price
column6: K is the strike price
column7: r is the risk-free rate
column9: and N(d) is the cumulative standard normal distribution function. The formula assumes no dividends and constant volatility.

title: Black-Scholes Put Formula
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula for pricing a European put option. P represents the put price
column5: and the other terms are as defined for the call formula. This can also be derived from put-call parity.

title: Black-Scholes d_1
notes: This equation defines the d_1 parameter in the Black-Scholes formula. d_1 combines the moneyness of the option (ln(S_0/K))
column5: the risk-free rate r
column6: the volatility sigma
column7: and time to expiration T. d_1 is used in both the call and put formulas.

title: Black-Scholes d_2
notes: This equation defines the d_2 parameter in the Black-Scholes formula. d_2 is simply d_1 minus sigma * sqrt(T). d_2 represents the probability that the option will be in the money at expiration under the risk-neutral measure.

title: Black-Scholes with Dividends
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula for a European call on a dividend-paying stock. The stock price S_0 is discounted by the continuous dividend yield q using e^{-qT}. This adjustment accounts for the expected dividend payments during the option's life.

title: Black-Scholes d_1 with Dividends
notes: This equation defines d_1 for dividend-paying stocks. The dividend yield q is subtracted from r in the numerator
column5: reflecting the reduced expected growth of the stock price due to dividends.

title: Delta (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a European call option. Delta_C represents the call delta
column5: and N(d_1) is the cumulative normal distribution evaluated at d_1. Delta measures the sensitivity of the option price to changes in the underlying stock price. For calls
column6: delta is between 0 and 1.

title: Delta (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a European put option. Delta_P represents the put delta. For puts
column5: delta is between -1 and 0
column6: reflecting the negative relationship between put price and stock price.

title: Gamma
notes: This equation calculates the gamma of a European option (same for calls and puts). Gamma represents the second derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. It measures the rate of change of delta and is highest for at-the-money options near expiration.

title: Normal PDF
notes: This is the probability density function of the standard normal distribution. N'(x) represents the PDF value at x
column5: and pi is approximately 3.14159. This function is used in calculating gamma and other higher-order Greeks.

title: Theta (Call)
equation_latex: Theta_C = -(S_0 * N'(d_1) * sigma) / (2 * sqrt(T)) - r * K * e^{-rT} * N(d_2)
notes: This equation calculates the theta of a European call option. Theta_C represents the call theta
column5: which measures the rate of time decay. Theta is typically negative
column6: reflecting that options lose value as time passes. The first term captures the volatility effect
column7: and the second term captures the interest rate effect.

title: Theta (Put)
equation_latex: Theta_P = -(S_0 * N'(d_1) * sigma) / (2 * sqrt(T)) + r * K * e^{-rT} * N(-d_2)
notes: This equation calculates the theta of a European put option. Theta_P represents the put theta. Unlike calls
column5: the interest rate term is positive for puts because higher rates increase the present value of the strike price received at expiration.

title: Vega
notes: This equation calculates the vega of a European option (same for calls and puts). Vega represents the sensitivity of the option price to changes in volatility. Vega is always positive
column5: meaning higher volatility increases option prices. Vega is highest for at-the-money options with longer time to expiration.

title: Rho (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the rho of a European call option. Rho_C represents the call rho
column5: which measures sensitivity to interest rate changes. For calls
column6: rho is typically positive because higher rates increase the present value of the strike price paid at expiration.

title: Rho (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the rho of a European put option. Rho_P represents the put rho. For puts
column5: rho is typically negative because higher rates decrease the present value of the strike price received at expiration.

title: Vanna
notes: This equation calculates the vanna of a European option. Vanna represents the sensitivity of delta to changes in volatility
column5: or equivalently
column6: the sensitivity of vega to changes in the underlying price. Vanna is important for managing volatility risk.

title: Charm
equation_latex: Charm = -N'(d_1) * (2rT - d_2 * sigma * sqrt(T)) / (2T * sigma * sqrt(T))
notes: This equation calculates the charm of a European option. Charm represents the sensitivity of delta to changes in time (delta decay). Charm is important for understanding how delta changes as expiration approaches.

title: Vomma
equation_latex: Vomma = S_0 * N'(d_1) * sqrt(T) * d_1 * d_2 / sigma
notes: This equation calculates the vomma (also called volga) of a European option. Vomma represents the sensitivity of vega to changes in volatility. Vomma is positive for most options
column5: meaning vega itself increases with volatility.

title: Veta
equation_latex: Veta = S_0 * N'(d_1) * sqrt(T) * (r * q + (d_1 * d_2 * sigma) / (2T))
notes: This equation calculates the veta of a European option. Veta represents the sensitivity of vega to changes in time (vega decay). Veta helps understand how volatility sensitivity changes as expiration approaches.

title: Speed
notes: This equation calculates the speed of a European option. Speed represents the third derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. Speed measures the rate of change of gamma and is important for understanding convexity risk.

title: Color
equation_latex: Color = -N'(d_1) / (2 * S_0 * T * sigma * sqrt(T)) * (1 + (2rT - d_2 * sigma * sqrt(T)) / (2T))
notes: This equation calculates the color of a European option. Color represents the sensitivity of gamma to changes in time (gamma decay). Color helps understand how the curvature of the option price changes as expiration approaches.

title: Zomma
notes: This equation calculates the zomma of a European option. Zomma represents the sensitivity of gamma to changes in volatility. Zomma is important for managing volatility risk in gamma-sensitive portfolios.

title: Implied Volatility (Definition)
notes: T
column5: r
column6: sigma_imp)
column7: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton
column8: This equation defines implied volatility as the volatility parameter that makes the Black-Scholes price equal to the market price. sigma_imp represents the implied volatility
column10: and C_BSM is the Black-Scholes price function. Implied volatility must be solved numerically.

title: Newton-Raphson for Implied Volatility
notes: This equation implements the Newton-Raphson method to solve for implied volatility. sigma_n is the current guess
column5: sigma_{n+1} is the updated guess
column6: C_BSM is the Black-Scholes price
column7: C_market is the market price
column8: and Vega is the option's vega. This iterative method converges quickly to the implied volatility.

title: Volatility Smile
notes: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton
column5: This equation represents the volatility smile phenomenon. sigma_imp represents the implied volatility
column6: which depends on moneyness (K/S_0) and time to expiration T. The smile shows that implied volatility varies with strike price
column7: contradicting the Black-Scholes assumption of constant volatility.

title: Volatility Skew
notes: This equation measures the volatility skew. Skew represents the slope of implied volatility across strike prices. sigma_imp(K_25) and sigma_imp(K_75) are the implied volatilities for 25-delta and 75-delta options respectively. Negative skew is common in equity markets.

title: Volatility Surface
notes: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton
column5: This equation represents the volatility surface
column6: which shows implied volatility as a function of both strike price K and time to expiration T. The surface captures the term structure of volatility and its dependence on moneyness.

title: Asian Option (Arithmetic Average)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of an arithmetic average Asian call option. The payoff depends on the arithmetic average of the underlying prices at n discrete times. Asian options reduce volatility risk because the average is less volatile than the terminal price.

title: Asian Option (Geometric Average)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a geometric average Asian call option. The payoff depends on the geometric average of the underlying prices. Geometric Asian options have closed-form pricing formulas unlike arithmetic Asian options.

title: Asian Option Price (Geometric)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation expresses the price of a geometric Asian option. C represents the option price
column6: S_G is the geometric average
column7: and E_Q is the expectation under the risk-neutral measure. The geometric average follows a lognormal distribution

title: Barrier Option (Up-and-Out Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of an up-and-out barrier call option. The option pays like a regular call only if the underlying price never reaches the barrier H during the option's life. If the barrier is breached
column6: the option becomes worthless (knocks out).

title: Barrier Option (Down-and-In Put)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a down-and-in barrier put option. The option pays like a regular put only if the underlying price reaches the barrier H at some point. The option activates (knocks in) when the barrier is breached.

title: Lookback Option (Floating Strike Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a floating strike lookback call option. The strike price is the minimum price observed during the option's life. Lookback options always end in the money and are more expensive than vanilla options.

title: Lookback Option (Fixed Strike Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a fixed strike lookback call option. The payoff depends on the maximum price observed during the option's life. This option allows the holder to benefit from the highest price reached.

title: Binary Option (Cash-or-Nothing Call)
equation_latex: Payoff = C if S_T > K else 0
notes: This equation gives the payoff of a cash-or-nothing binary call option. The option pays a fixed cash amount C if the underlying price exceeds the strike at expiration
column5: otherwise it pays nothing. Binary options have discontinuous payoffs.

title: Binary Option (Asset-or-Nothing Call)
equation_latex: Payoff = S_T if S_T > K else 0
notes: This equation gives the payoff of an asset-or-nothing binary call option. The option pays the underlying asset price if it exceeds the strike at expiration
column5: otherwise it pays nothing. This option is similar to a digital option but pays the asset value.

title: Compound Option (Call on Call)
column6: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column7: This equation gives the payoff of a call on a call (compound option). The underlying is a call option with strike K_2 and maturity T_2. The compound option gives the right to buy this underlying call for strike K_1 at time T_1.

title: Chooser Option
column5: P(S_T
column6: K
column9: This equation gives the payoff of a chooser option. At the choice date
column10: the holder can choose whether the option becomes a call or a put. The payoff is the maximum of the call and put values at expiration.

title: Exchange Option
notes: T
column6: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column7: This equation gives the payoff of an exchange option. The option gives the right to exchange asset 2 for asset 1 at expiration. S_1
column9: T are the prices of the two assets at expiration. This generalizes the standard option where one asset is cash (the strike price).

title: Basket Option
column5: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column6: This equation gives the payoff of a basket call option. The underlying is a basket (portfolio) of n assets with weights w_i. Basket options reduce transaction costs compared to buying options on individual assets.

title: Spread Option
notes: T - K
column6: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column7: This equation gives the payoff of a spread call option. The payoff depends on the difference between two asset prices minus a spread K. Spread options are used to hedge the price difference between related assets (e.g.

title: Rainbow Option
column5: T) - K
column7: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column8: This equation gives the payoff of a rainbow option (minimum of two assets). The payoff depends on the minimum of two asset prices. Rainbow options involve multiple underlying assets and are used in commodity and currency markets.

title: Forward Start Option
notes: This equation prices a forward start option that begins at time T_1 and expires at T_2. The option starts at-the-money forward. Forward start options are used in employee stock option plans.

title: Cliquet Option
column5: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column6: This equation gives the payoff of a cliquet option. The payoff depends on the product of (1 + max(R_i
column7: 0)) where R_i is the return over each period. Cliquet options provide participation in upside while limiting downside.

title: Bermudan Option
notes: This equation states that Bermudan options (exercisable on specified dates) are at least as valuable as European options (exercisable only at expiration). C_Bermudan represents the Bermudan option price
column5: and C_European is the European option price. The early exercise optionality adds value.

title: Digital Option Price
notes: This equation prices a cash-or-nothing digital call option. C represents the option price
column5: and N(d_2) is the risk-neutral probability that S_T > K. The price is simply the discounted expected payoff under the risk-neutral measure.

title: Gap Option Payoff
equation_latex: Payoff = S_T - K_2 if S_T > K_1 else 0
notes: This equation gives the payoff of a gap call option. The option has two strike prices: K_1 triggers exercise
column5: and K_2 determines the payoff amount. Gap options can have negative intrinsic value when K_2 > K_1.

title: Power Option Payoff
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation gives the payoff of a power call option. The payoff depends on the underlying price raised to power a. Power options provide leveraged exposure to the underlying asset.

title: Quanto Option
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options
column5: This equation expresses the price of a quanto option. The option pays in the domestic currency but the payoff depends on a foreign asset. S_T^f is the foreign asset price
column6: and X_T is the exchange rate. Quanto options eliminate currency risk.

title: Asian Option Delta Approximation
notes: This equation approximates the delta of an arithmetic Asian option. The delta depends on the relationship between the current price and the prices at which the average is calculated. This approximation is used because there's no closed-form formula.

title: Option Elasticity
notes: This equation calculates the elasticity of an option. Elasticity represents the percentage change in option price for a 1% change in the underlying price. For calls
column5: elasticity is greater than 1 (options are more volatile than the underlying).

title: Leverage
notes: This equation calculates the leverage of an option position. Leverage represents how many shares of underlying you effectively control with one option. Deep in-the-money options have leverage close to 1
column5: while out-of-the-money options have very high leverage.

title: Option Beta
notes: This equation relates option beta to underlying beta. Beta_option represents the option's beta (sensitivity to market returns)
column5: and Beta_underlying is the underlying asset's beta. Options amplify the beta of the underlying.

title: Probability of ITM (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the risk-neutral probability that a call option expires in the money. The probability is N(d_2)
column5: where N is the cumulative normal distribution. This is different from the real-world probability of exercise.

title: Probability of ITM (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the risk-neutral probability that a put option expires in the money. The probability is N(-d_2). This probability is used in option pricing and risk management.

title: Expected Terminal Stock Price
notes: This equation gives the expected terminal stock price under the risk-neutral measure. E[S_T] represents the expectation
column5: S_0 is the current price
column6: r is the risk-free rate
column7: and T is time to expiration. Under risk-neutral valuation
column8: assets grow at the risk-free rate.

title: Option Value Decomposition
notes: This equation decomposes an option's value into intrinsic and time components. C represents the total option value. Intrinsic value is the immediate exercise value
column5: and time value reflects the probability of future favorable price movements.

title: Early Exercise Premium (American Put)
notes: This equation calculates the early exercise premium for an American put option. EEP represents the extra value from the early exercise right. This premium is positive for deep in-the-money puts on non-dividend stocks.

title: Optimal Exercise Boundary (American Put)
notes: q
column5: sigma
column6: T - t)
column7: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals
column8: This equation defines the optimal exercise boundary for an American put. S* represents the critical stock price below which early exercise is optimal. The boundary depends on the strike

title: Option Theta Decay
notes: This equation approximates the theta decay near expiration. The dominant term is the volatility term
column5: which causes rapid time decay for at-the-money options. This approximation highlights why theta becomes very negative near expiration.

title: Gamma Scalping Profit
notes: This equation estimates the profit from gamma scalping (delta-hedging). The gamma term captures profit from convexity when the underlying moves
column5: and the theta term represents the time decay cost. Gamma scalping can be profitable in volatile markets.

title: Delta Hedging Error
notes: This equation estimates the hedging error from discrete delta hedging. The error comes from the convexity (gamma) of the option price. More frequent rebalancing reduces this error but increases transaction costs.

title: Option Implied Distribution
equation_latex: f(S_T) = (1 / (S_T * sigma * sqrt(2 * pi * T))) * exp(-(ln(S_T/S_0) - (r - 0.5 * sigma^2) * T)^2 / (2 * sigma^2 * T))
notes: This equation gives the risk-neutral probability density function of the terminal stock price under Black-Scholes assumptions. f(S_T) represents the lognormal distribution
column5: which is the foundation of Black-Scholes pricing.

title: Risk-Neutral Valuation
notes: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton
column5: This is the fundamental risk-neutral valuation formula. C represents the option price
column6: which equals the discounted expected payoff under the risk-neutral measure Q. This formula is the foundation of all derivatives pricing.

title: Martingale Property
notes: This equation expresses the martingale property of discounted stock prices under the risk-neutral measure. S_t represents the stock price at time t
column5: and F_t is the information available at time t. This property is fundamental to no-arbitrage pricing.

title: Change of Numeraire
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula expressed using the change of numeraire technique. The first term uses the stock as numeraire
column5: and the second term uses the money market account as numeraire. This technique is powerful for pricing complex derivatives.

title: Option Price as Integral
equation_latex: C = e^{-rT} * integral_K^inf (S_T - K) * f(S_T) dS_T
notes: This equation expresses the option price as an integral over the terminal stock price. C represents the call price
column5: and f(S_T) is the risk-neutral probability density. This integral representation is useful for understanding option pricing.
